maml:description.maml:para: Update SAN Manager configuration
Updates an existing SAN Manager configuration. Can update the hostname/IP Address and credentials. At least one optional parameter must be provided.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
Enable Secure WBEM communications to Brocade SAN Network Advisor.
Enable Secure WBEM communications to Brocade SAN Network Advisor.
Updated Hostname or IP Address of the SAN Manager.
Updated Password used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.
Updated TCP Port of the SAN Manager.
Aliases [-name] Resource Object (from Get-HPOVSanManager) or Name of the SAN Manager to update. If specifying a resource Name, the ApplianceConnection parameter is required.

The SNMPv3 Authentication Level. Allowed values are:
* None - No Security is required, only the SNMPv3 UserName is provided. * AuthOnly - SNMPv3 Authentication Encryption Security Level only. Must also provide -SnmpAuthProtocol and -SnmpAuthPassword parameters. * AuthAndPriv - SNMPv3 Authentication Encryption Security and Privacy Levels. Must also provide -SnmpAuthProtocol, -SnmpAuthPassword, -SnmpPrivProtocol and -SnmpPrivPassword parameters.
SNMPv3 UserName Password.

SNMPv3 Password Encryption Protocol. Allowed values are:
* SHA * MD5
SNMPv3 Privacy Encryption Password.

SNMPv3 Privacy Protocol. Allowed values are:
* AES * DES
The SNMPv3 Community User Name.
Updated Username used to authenticate and manage the SAN Manager.
SAN Manager resource from Get-HPOVSanManager.
Update async task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Get-HPOVSanManager bna.domain.com -ApplianceConnection hpov.domain.com | Set-HPOVSanManager -hostname bna.newdomain.com | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete

dev:remarks.dev:para: Get the SAN Manager using Get-HPOVSanManager, and pipling the resource in order to update the hostname value.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Set-HPOVSanManager -name BNA.contoso.com -hostname bna.newdomain.com -ApplianceConnection hpov.domain.com | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete

dev:remarks.dev:para: Update the existing Brocade Network Advisor SAN Manager's hostname with the new value.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Set-HPOVSanManager -name BNA.contoso.com -username newadmin -password updatedpassword -ApplianceConnection hpov.domain.com | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete

dev:remarks.dev:para: Update the existing Brocade Network Advisor SAN Manager's username and password.

maml:description.maml:para: Set the power state of a server.

[Deprecated] Please note this Cmdlet is being deprecated for in favor of Start-HPOVServer, Stop-HPOVServer and Restart-HPOVServer Cmdlets. Please update your scripts accordingly.
Set the power state of the server using the virtual power button.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
[Object]$ApplianceConnection = (${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default)

Optional setting to control the virtual power button. Default is MomentaryPress, other options are PressAndHold, ColdBoot and Reset
Current state powerState powerControl Result ------------- ---------- ------------ ------ On On MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On On ColdBoot OK On On Reset OK On Off MomentaryPress OK (just have to assume that there�s an OS on the server and it will power off the server someday�) On Off PressAndHold OK On Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control On Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On MomentaryPress OK Off On PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off On Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off MomentaryPress Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off PressAndHold Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off ColdBoot Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control Off Off Reset Exception: cannot achieve desired power state via the specified power control
Optional power state. Default is On, other option is Off
Aliases [-name, -uri, -serverUri] The server object, URI or Name, or can be a Server Profile object.
Server Hardware Name
Server Hardware Resource
Server Profile Resource
Async task that tracks the power state change

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVServer "Encl1, Bay 1" | Set-HPOVServerPower | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete

dev:remarks.dev:para: Power on the specific server device by passing the Server Object via pipeline to Set-HPOVServerPower.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-HPOVServer "Encl1, Bay 1" | Set-HPOVServerPower -powerState off -powerControl PressAndHold

dev:remarks.dev:para: Power off the specific server device by passing the Server Object via pipeline to Set-HPOVServerPower.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Get-HPOVServerProfile "Profile1" -ApplianceConnection "MyAppliance.domain.com" | Set-HPOVServerPower -powerState On -powerControl MomentaryPress

dev:remarks.dev:para: Power on the specific server hardware by using the Server Profile object.

maml:description.maml:para: Configure appliance SMTP Reporting settings.

This Cmdlet configures the SMTP settings for the appliance. SMTP settings include deining the Sender EMAIL Address, SMTP relay server address, SMTP relay server TCP port, optional password, and if SMTP alerting is enabled or disabled.
Currently, HPE OneView does not support Secure SMTP, even though the TCP Port can be modified. Using the SmtpPort parameter is to specify an alternate TCP Port than the default TCP/25.
Disable SMTP Email Alerting.
Enable SMTP Email Alerting

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Provide an SMTP Password to authenticate to the SMTP Server. Object can either be a String or SecureString value. This password will be sent in clear text to the SMTP server.
Aliases [-SmtpPort] Provide an alternate TCP port number than the default SMTP port value 25/TCP.
Specify the Sender Email Address for the appliance.
Aliases [-SmtpServer] Specify the SMTP Relay Server if DNS does not contain a valid DNS MX record for the sender email address domain name.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.
If successful, returns an async task resource that can be monitored with status and progress of the saved email notification operation.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Set the appliance's SMTP Sender Email Address to 'hpov-alerts@contoso.com' and enable SMTP Email Alerting.
Set the appliance's SMTP Sender Email Address to 'hpov-alerts@contoso.com' and enable SMTP Email Alerting.

maml:description.maml:para: Set SNMP Read Community.

Set a new SNMP Read Community value on the appliance. Updating this value will cause the appliance to refresh the managed devices with the updated Read-Only SNMP Community string. This does not update the SNMP trap destination(s) for Logical Interconnects or Logical Interconnect Groups.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
The name of the new SNMP Read-Only Community.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.
None.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Set the appliance SNMP Read Community string to the new value.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing Storage Volume resource.
This Cmdlet will help modify an existing Storage Volume resource. Only the Volume Name, Description, Capcity, volume shared state and permenance can be modified.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default

Aliases [-size] New Max volume capacity in GB. Volume capacity can be increased to maximum of 16 TiB. Decreasing the capacity of volume is not supported.
Before increasing the capacity of fully provisioned volumes, ensure that the storage pool has enough capacity to support the operation. The update operation might fail if there is not enough space available in the storage pool.
e.g. 20 to specify 20GB.
Updated description for the volume.
Include this switch to mark the Storage Volume as a Shareable resource for shared volume access. Default: Private
The Storage Pool Name or Object to be used for Volume Snapshots.
Source Storage Volume object to process, retreived from Get-HPOVStorageVolume.
Updated Storage Volume Name.
Storage Pool Name or URI
Storage Pool resource object
Async create task

dev:remarks.dev:para: Update 'ProdVol1' volume size to 160GB.

maml:description.maml:para: Set Storage Volume Template Global Policy

By default, Storage Volumes can be created without reference to a Storage Volume Template. This Cmdlet will allow the administrator to change the global policy setting. Use with caution, as this will prevent copying Server Profiles that contain attached Storage Volumes.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
Switch to disable the policy
Switch to enable the policy

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.
Returned boolean value after changing policy.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplatePolicy Appliance Name Value --------- ---- ----- MyAppliance.domain.com StorageVolumeTemplateRequired true MyAppliance2.domain.com StorageVolumeTemplateRequired true
PS C:\> Set-HPOVStorageVolumeTemplatePolicy -disable
Appliance Name Value --------- ---- ----- MyAppliance.domain.com StorageVolumeTemplateRequired false MyAppliance2.domain.com StorageVolumeTemplateRequired false

dev:remarks.dev:para: Get the Storage Volume Template Global Policy setting, then disable it for all connected appliances.

maml:description.maml:para: Modify an existing user account.

Modify or update an existing local user account on the management appliance. This Cmdlet will not update the password or roles of the currently logged in user account. To update your HPE OneView appliance local account's password, please use the Set-HPOVUserPassword Cmdlet.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s). If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Disable the local user account.
Updated Email Address of the User Account.
Enable the local user account.
Updated Full Name of the User Account.
Updated mobile phone number
Updated office phone of the User Account.
New password for the user account. Passwords must be at least 8 characters.

An array list of roles to assign the user to. Allowed values are:
* Infrastructure Administrator * Read Only * Backup Administrator * Network Administrator * Server Administrator * Storage administrator
The name or object of the user account to be updated.
The object of the user account to be updated.
HPE OneView local user account object.
If successful, returns a user resource.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-HPOVUser -Username Sally -Roles @("server administrator","network administrator")

dev:remarks.dev:para: Update the user account 'Sally' with new roles.
Update the user account 'Sally' with a new password.

maml:description.maml:para: Update current user account password.

This Cmdlet provides the ability to update the current user account password. Only HPE OneView appliance local account passwords will be changed. This Cmdlet does not assist with modifying or updating an LDAP or Active Directory user account's password.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default

Aliases [-CurrentPassword]
The current password of the user account. If omitted, the cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.

Aliases [-NewPassword]
The new password to be set for the user account. If omitted, the Cmdlet will prompt for the users password as a secure string.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Update your HPE OneView account password to the new value on all connected appliances.

maml:description.maml:para: Assign or change roles for an existing user.
Changes current roles of a user with a given set of roles. It is not possible to modify roles of the built-in administrator, or your own user account.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s). If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Aliases [-user, -username] The name of the user account to have a role assigned.

Aliases [-rolenames] Array of roles for the user. May include one of more of:
* Infrastructure Administrator * Read Only * Backup Administrator * Network Administrator * Server Administrator * Storage Administrator

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

dev:type.maml:name: Updated user account with new role(s).

maml:description.maml:para: Updated user account with new role(s).

dev:remarks.dev:para: Set the Server Administrator role for Sally's user account.

maml:description.maml:para: Generate firmware report

Use this Cmdlet to generate a Firmware Report for various object types. Supported objects are:
* EG (Enclosure Group) * Enclosure * Server * Interconnect

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default

Name or Object of the Firmware Baseline to report against what's installed. If omitted, the Cmdlet will take the following Policies in order:
* Server Profile (If one is applied and Baseline is set) * Logical Interconnect (If one is set) * Enclosure Group (If none of the others have been set)
Indicate to export the report to a CSV file.

Directory location where to save the report. The saved filename will be generated from the following template name:
'FirmwareReport_yyyy-MM-ddTHH.mm.ss.ff.fffZzzz.csv'

The managed resource Object to generate the report for. Accepted object types are:
* EG (Enclosure Group) * Enclosure * Server * Interconnect
E.g. Get-HPOVInterconnect | Show-HPOVFirmwareReport
By specifying an Enclosure Group, all associated Logical Enclosures and Enclosures will be included in the report.
Firmware Baseline Object

Resource object to generate Firmware Report for.
E.g. Get-HPOVEnclosureGroup 'My EG1' | Show-HPOVFirmwareReport
Firmware report.
When using the Export paramter, a CSV file is created.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Display a firmware report of all associated Logical Enclosures/Enclosures to 'Production EG' Enclosure Group currently managed by the appliance.
Display a firmware report of the 'Encl1' Enclosure resource, and components (servers, interconnects and Onboard Administrators) currently managed by the appliance.

maml:description.maml:para: Show the MAC Table for Logical Interconnect resource(s).

This Cmdlet will help show the MAC Table of Logical Interconnect resources. The REST API currently limits the first 100 MAC addresses from the MAC table, regardless of the number of MAC Addresses learned in the table.
Use the -Network parameter to specify the Network Name to display learned MAC Addresses. You can export the results to a CSV file, by providing the full path and filename to export to, using the -ExportFile parameter.
To display the results in a formatted list, use the -List parameter.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Aliases [-x, -exportFile] Export to a CSV, provide the full path and filename.
Aliases [-name, -li] The Name, URI, Logical Interconnect Resource or an array of either to display the MAC Address tables from.
Provide a MAC Address to locate in the MAC Table.
Provide the Network Name to filter the MAC Table results for.
Logical Inteconnect URI or Name
An Array of Logical Interconnect resource URI's, Names or Objects.
Logical Interconnect Resource Object
Collection of MAC Address Table entries.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Return as many MAC Addresses allowed by the API for all Logical Interconnect resources.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Show-HPOVLogicalInterconnectMacTable -network VLAN100 Done. 1 logical interconnect group(s) found. Done. 1 network resource(s) found.
Enclosure Interconnect Interface Address Type Network VLAN --------- ------------ --------- ------- ---- ------- ---- Encl1 interconnect 2 LAG 27 38:22:D6:35:5A:62 Learned VLAN100 30 Encl1 interconnect 1 LAG 26 38:22:D6:35:5A:62 Learned VLAN100 30 Encl1 interconnect 1 LAG 26 78:AC:C0:72:E5:D9 Learned VLAN100 30

dev:remarks.dev:para: Display all available MAC Addresses learned in 'VLAN100' network in all Logical Interconnect resources, and display in a formatted table.
Retrieve the available MAC Addresses learned in 'VLAN100' network, and export to C:\reports\Encl1-LI_vlan100_mactable.csv

maml:description.maml:para: Display Interconnect Port Statistics.

This Cmdlet will display the utilization (Format-Table view) or error (Format-List) statistics of a given Interconnect or Interconnect Port. The default view is Format-Table. Piping output to Format-List will display error statistics.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s). If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
The Interconnect resource the Port ID is a member of.
The name of the Interconnect Port ID (i.e. X1 or D5) to retrieve. If no Port ID is provided, all Ports of the Interconnect will be returned.
An Interconnect Port object.
Ethernet Uplink Port statistics.
Ethernet Uplink Port statistics.
Collection of multiple Interconnect Port statistics.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Show-HPOVPortStatistics -interconnect "Encl1, Interconnect 1" -port X1 Port Type: Ethernet
Name Rx Kb/s Tx Kb/s Rx Packets Tx Packets Rx Non-Unicast PPS Tx Non-Unicast PPS ---- ------- ------- ---------- ---------- ------------------ ------------------ X1 5Kbps (1min) 0Kbps (1min) 6pps (1min) 0pps (1min) 6pps (1min) 0pps (1min)

dev:remarks.dev:para: Displays the interface throughput statistics for X1 in a Format-Table display.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Show-HPOVPortStatistics -interconnect "Encl1, Interconnect 1" -port X1 | FL Port Type: Ethernet
Name : X4 Rx Kb/s : 5Kbps (1min) Tx Kb/s : 0Kbps (1min) In Discards : Out Discards : In Errors : Out Errors : CRC Errors Rx/Tx : MTU Exceeded Discards Rx/Tx : Giants Rx/Tx :

dev:remarks.dev:para: Displays the interface error statistics for X1 in a Format-List display.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> (Get-HPOVInterconnect 'Encl1, Interconnect 1').ports | ? name -eq X1 | Show-HPOVPortStatistics

dev:remarks.dev:para: Pipe an Interconnect Port object to Show-HPOVPortStatistics and show the interface throughput statistics.

maml:description.maml:para: View Managed SAN FC Endpoints.

This Cmdlet will dispay the Managed SAN endpoints, or FC addresses, their node information, and Zone Name. By default, all SAN endpoints will be returned. You can filter the results based on Managed SAN resource or WWN address.

Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
THe Managed SAN Resource Object or Name. Cannot be combined with the WWN parameter.

Managed SAN resource from Get-HPOVManagedSan
Async task.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Show-HPOVSanEndpoint Appliance WWN Port Type Online SAN Name Zone Name --------- --- --------- ------ -------- --------- hpov-tot2 10:00:F6:9F:5F:70:00:02 N_Port False SAN1_1 Node_1_8 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:08:DF N_Port True SAN1_1 Node_1_8 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:08:E3 N_Port True SAN1_1 Node_1_8 hpov-tot2 10:00:F6:9F:5F:70:00:00 N_Port False SAN1_0 Node_1_7 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:08:E2 N_Port True SAN1_0 Node_1_7 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:08:DE N_Port True SAN1_0 Node_1_7 hpov-tot2 AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AA N_Port False SAN1_0 dummy_zone hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:09:03 N_Port True SAN1_0 hpov-tot2 00:00:4A:2B:21:E0:00:1B N_Port True SAN1_1 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:09:04 N_Port True SAN1_1 hpov-tot2 00:00:4A:2B:21:E0:00:14 N_Port True SAN1_0 hpov-tot2 00:00:4A:2B:21:E0:00:0D N_Port True SAN1_1 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:09:00 N_Port True SAN1_1 hpov-tot2 20:00:00:02:AC:00:08:FF N_Port True SAN1_0 hpov-tot2 00:00:4A:2B:21:E0:00:06 N_Port True SAN1_0

maml:description.maml:para: Start an HPOV Library Verbose Trace.

This Cmdlet will assist the user in setting up the PowerShell environment to generate and capture Verbose output from HPOV Library Cmdlets. Once this Cmdlet has been executed, the prior HPOV Cmdlets can be executed, without the need of using the `-Cerbose` switch.
Cmdlet output will be captured using the built-in Microsoft PowerShell Start-Transcript provider. A transcript trace file will be saved in either the current working directory, or specified using the `-Location` parameter.
Use the Stop-HPOVLibraryTrace to complete the verbose trace capture.
Please know that this Cmdlet is currently not supported in the Windows PowerShell ISE.

Specify the directory where the .trace file will be created. A file with the following format will be created:
'{Date}_HPOV__transcript.trace', where date is derived from `Get-Date -UFormat %y%m%d%H%M`
Default Value: (PWD).Path

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.
None.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Start a new library trace, which will create a file in the `C:\Temp` directory.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop an HPE OneView appliance.

This Cmdlet will allow the administrator to stop/shutdown the appliance. Shutdown of the appliance will cause all users to be disconnected and all ongoing tasks to be interrupted.
Only the Infrastructure (Full) Administrator may restart the appliance.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s).
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
Connected Appliance Session.
Collection of HPOneView.Appliance.Connection objects.
Warning message the appliance is stopping
Generated error message

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-HPOVMgmt appliance.contoso.com Administrator P@ssw0rd PS C:\> Stop-HPOVAppliance

dev:remarks.dev:para: Shutdown the appliance.
Shutdown all connected appliances, disable confirmation.

maml:description.maml:para: Stop HPOV Library Verbose Trace.
After starting a Library Trace with the Start-HPOVLibraryTrace Cmdlet, the trace file is closed and can be used to analyze API calls and Cmdlet interactions.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: Power off Server Resource.

Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Return Async task object and do not wait for task to complete. By default, the Cmdlet will wait for the task to complete.
Use this parameter to request the 'Press and Hold' virtual power button method, which will forcable power off a server without a graceful shutdown.
A Server hardware or Server Profile resource object.
Server Hardware Resource
Server Profile Resource
Async task that tracks the power state change
Multiple Async tasks.

maml:description.maml:para: Update or Refresh an enclosure.

This Cmdlet will update or refresh an enclosure. An Enclosure Refresh will instruct HPE OneView to go inventory the enclosure and update any missing management configurations.
Use the -Refresh switch for scenarios where adding an enclosure results in a warning or critical error when a BL server cannot be managed due to an existing _HPOneViewAdmin account that cannot be reset or too many HP SSO Certificates are configured (iLO supports no more than 5) and you have manually cleared the HP SSO list and/or removed the _HPOneViewAdmin account.
Immediately return async task resource to be monitored.
Provide the Enclosure name, URI or Object, or [System.Array] of names, URIs or Objects to refresh/update.
Reapply the Enclosure Configuration.
Refresh the enclosure to fix configuration issues.
Single Enclosure resource.
Multiple Enclosure resources.
Async task Resource object for monitoring the enclosure import process.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Refresh all available enclosures, from all connected sessions.
Refresh 'Enclosure1' enclosure.

maml:description.maml:para: Update or Refresh a Logical Enclosure.

This Cmdlet will update or refresh a Logical Enclosure. A Refresh will instruct HPE OneView to go inventory the enclosure and update any missing management configurations. An Update will perform Logical Enclosure compliance remediation with the parent Enclosure Group.
Use the -Refresh switch for scenarios where adding an enclosure results in a warning or critical error when a BL server cannot be managed due to an existing _HPOneViewAdmin account that cannot be reset or too many HP SSO Certificates are configured (iLO supports no more than 5) and you have manually cleared the HP SSO list and/or removed the _HPOneViewAdmin account.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectSessions} | ? Default
Do not wait for the update task to complete,and return the task object for caller to monitor.

Aliases [-le]
Provide the Logical Enclosure name, URI or Object, or [System.Array] of names, URIs or Objects to refresh/update.
Reapply the Enclosure Configuration.

Aliases [-UpdateFromEG]
Useing this switch will update the Logical Enclosure to be compliant with the Parent Enclosure Group.
Use this parameter to identify what is different or changed from the parent group policy.
Single Enclosure resource.
Multiple Enclosure resources.
Async task Resource object for monitoring the enclosure import process.
Multiple async task Resource object for monitoring the enclosure import process.

The Cmdlet will return a compare object with the Parent and Child object and settings that are different. Otherwise, no object is returned.
Property Name | Description ========================================================== InputObject | Compared Object Property or Setting Value ---------------------------------------------------------- ParentSetting | Name of Property or Setting ---------------------------------------------------------- ChildSetting | Name of Property or Setting ---------------------------------------------------------- Parent | Name of Parent Object ---------------------------------------------------------- Child | Name of Child Object ---------------------------------------------------------- Description | Description Name of difference ----------------------------------------------------------

dev:remarks.dev:para: Refresh all available Logical Enclosures, from all connected sessions.
Refresh all available Logical Enclosures, from all connected sessions.
Refresh 'Enclosure1' Logical Enclosure.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a Logical Interconnect.

When a Logical Interconnect is inconsistent with its parent Logical Interconnect Group, it can be made consistent with this Cmdlet. Updating the Logical Interconnect with its parent could cause an network outage depending on the changes about to be applied.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one or more HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object(s) or Name property value(s). If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Switch to reapply the Logical Interconnect configuration. This does NOT update the Logical Interconnect from the parent Logical Interconnect Group.
Aliases [-li, -uri, -name] The Logical Interconnect object(s), name(s) or uris(s) to be updated.
Use this parameter to identify what is different or changed from the parent group policy.
Logical Interconnect Name or URI
Single Logical Interconnect resource object
Collection of Logical Interconnect Names, URIs or System.Management.Automation.PSCustomObject
Single async Update Task.
Multiple async Update Tasks.

The Cmdlet will return a compare object with the Parent and Child object and settings that are different. Otherwise, no object is returned.
Property Name | Description ========================================================== InputObject | Compared Object Property or Setting Value ---------------------------------------------------------- ParentSetting | Name of Property or Setting ---------------------------------------------------------- ChildSetting | Name of Property or Setting ---------------------------------------------------------- Parent | Name of Parent Object ---------------------------------------------------------- Child | Name of Child Object ---------------------------------------------------------- Description | Description Name of difference ----------------------------------------------------------

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $task = Update-HPOVLogicalInterconnect -name Encl1-LI PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task

dev:remarks.dev:para: Perform an update of the Encl1-LI Logical Interconnect. Will be prompted for confirmation.
Perform an update of the Encl1-LI Logical Interconnect. Disable confirmation prompt.
Search for all Logical Interconnects and update them.

maml:description.maml:para: Refresh the state of a server resource.

By using this Cmdlet, you can manually refresh the connection between the appliance and server hardware by using the Refresh option on the Actions menu. You must refresh server hardware if it has lost connectivity or if it is not synchronized with the appliance. Connectivity loss can occur during normal appliance operation. A device can become unsynchronized if you make changes to it outside of the appliance

Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.

maml:description.maml:para: Wait for Appliance services to start.

Internal module helper function to wait for the appliance services to start. This helper function will be called by Send-HPOVRequest when the [System.Net.WebRequest] GetResponse() client generates an [Net.WebException] exception. Then, this function will be called to provide the caller with an indication that the appliance is starting its services. This will display two prompts:
1. An initial text-based progress bar while the System.Net.WebRequest is able to access the web service on the appliance to begin polling for service startup status. 2. Write-Progress indicator displaying the overall service startup.
If any service fails to startup, this function will cause a terminating error, informing the caller to go visit the appliance kiosk console to get more information about the startup error.
When the appliance successfully starts, this function will return.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify the appliance FQDN or IP Address without a valid connection created by using Connect-HPOVMgmt.

dev:type.maml:name: None. You cannot pipe objects to this Cmdlet.

maml:description.maml:para: The Write-Progress Cmdlet is used to display the startup progress.

dev:remarks.dev:para: Wait for the appliance to start, and specify the appliance name.

maml:description.maml:para: Wait for a task to complete.

HPE OneView utilizes a task subsystem for operations that will take longer than 200ms, and will execute them Asyncrounously. An async task resource object is created and returned to the caller once the request has passed validation.
This blocking Cmdlet assists a caller with monitoring a specific task resource, and will wait for the given task to "complete" (get to a terminal state, including error) or timeout. The Cmdlet accepts either the task URI or resource object via pipeline.
Once the task is no longer in a running state, the cmlet will return the task resource object. The caller should examine the taskState property/key for the final task status.

Aliases [-Appliance]
Specify one HPOneView.Appliance.Connection object or Name property value. If Resource object is provided via Pipeline, the ApplianceConnection property of the object will be used.
Default Value: ${Global:ConnectedSessions} | ? Default
Aliases [-taskUri] The uri of the task resource to wait for.
The timespan to wait for the task to complete. Default is to wait for 20 minutes.
Task URI
Task resource object.
The finished Task object that includes the task result.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete /rest/tasks/F08EE040-DBA7-4806-BB62-993DD0CB4250 PS C:\> Waiting for task to complete...Task completed successfully!

dev:remarks.dev:para: Wait for task to complete.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Wait-HPOVTaskComplete $task -timeout (New-TimeSpan -minute 10) PS C:\> Waiting for task to complete...Task completed successfully!

dev:remarks.dev:para: Wait for task to complete, modifying the default timeout to 10 minutes.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $svr = Get-HPOVServer "ServerA" PS C:\> $taskResults = New-HPOVServerProfile -name "Profile 1" -server $svr | Wait-HPOVTaskComplete

dev:remarks.dev:para: Retreive the server details for ServerA, create a Server Profile and pass via pipeline the task resource object.
